petitioner.name: MAYO FOUNDATION FOR MEDICAL EDUCATION AND RESEARCH, ET AL.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Olson, are -- are all institutions that employ residents schools?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But it might -- it might be relevant, because it would be unseemly, perhaps, to have residents who are not working at, quote, "schools," subject to the FICA tax, and other residents whose training is approximately the same escape the tax.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But you can't give me the reality there.  Are all resident programs conducted in schools, or are there resident programs that would not qualify because they take place in institutions that are not schools?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Mr. Olson, are residents supervised their entire 40 to 80 hours?  Is there an attending physician standing over their shoulder and looking at what they're doing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What I -- how I look at this case is:  How do you draw the line between a student who is working and a worker who is studying?  So the issue for me is:  Is the Treasury Department's identification of how to draw that line unreasonable? Do we owe them deference?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Let's use the example that's been floated around the briefs:  the general counsel of the university who takes classes to increase his knowledge.  Is he a student who is working, or is he a worker who's studying?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Why isn't the general counsel who's going to, let's assume, either three classes a week or 6 -- 6 hours of classes, is working 40 hours as general counsel, and he's regularly enrolled  in classes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Why isn't he part of the exemption?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So why wouldn't common sense lead you to the conclusion that if someone is working 40 unsupervised hours without an attending physician at their side, taking care of patients, that that's really not a student?  That's what the Treasury Department is saying.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You don't think receiving $50,000 or $60,000 a year is enough to make you an employee of someone?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But why doesn't that -- assume it's not the general counsel of the university but a lawyer working in the general counsel's office.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: He's being supervised by the general counsel, his work's being reviewed, and he's attending classes at night.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, what they want to achieve is a higher long-term pay, but they can go out and work as doctors.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I understood that 15 percent of the physicians were not board certified.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So how about the architect residents who are working in universities? Are they medical -- like medical residents as well?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Olson, why not read that provision -- now we are going to the statute -- if such service is performed by a student, et cetera, as saying, look, there's a student status, and the service is distinct from the student's status? Take the typical work/study program in a college.  That would seem to fit this language to a tee. There's a student, and the student is working part time, but you are -- there -- there is no independent significance to the term "student" as you read the text; that is, the student and the services are all together.  It's not, "I am a student here and I perform services there."  It's -- the student is -- the education is the service.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But wouldn't -- wouldn't this fit the work/study student who is studying philosophy and then he's working in the, say, speech department?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The -- it seems to me that -- what came into my mind when I read these words was a work/study program where the student is studying and that's the status of student.  The work is separate from that.  It's not necessarily to advance the person's education.  It's to give the student some money.  So that's what I thought -- I thought that this was -- this was describing student status, okay; and the student is also working for some money. But you seem to say that the service -- that -- that it's -- the student status is not  independent from the service.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: No, I have in mind the typical work/study program.  The -- the student signs up for work/study and may be assigned to work in the administration, helping out with clerical things there. But the student status is one thing; the services are another. Now, that, I assume, would be covered, that the earnings of the student in the work/study program would not be subject to FICA?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, those five courts did it before -- most of those opinions were rendered before the new regulation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Only one of them --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is it -- is it -- the -- the answer to Justice Ginsburg's question -- I was uncertain.  Suppose a student is working 45 hours a week in the grounds department cutting lawns, and he does -- cutting the school lawn, and he earns enough money to help with his way through college.  Now, I thought, under this, that he is not within this statute because it's 45 hours and not 40?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That it's not -- okay. So -- so, what they're doing is -- it started out with the word "student" and the word "service performed" in the statute.  Then, for many, many years, they have talked about the employment, how it has to be an incident to the study.  And "incident" is the key word. And so now what they've done is interpret their own word "incident" as saying if it bulks too large in comparison with the -- with the studying, it's  not incident to the study; it's a separate thing.  And that's true whether it happens to be medical school or it happens to be lawn mowing.  They can't -- they don't want it as so big in comparison to the study that it's not really part of trying to get the study.  It's just too big.  And they use the 40 for that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.  Now, if you're going to admit the word "incident to," if you're saying they have the right to put the word "incident to," why don't they have the right to define "incident to" in part in terms of 40 hours a week?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Mr. Olson --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- everyone learns. Aren't you learning today -- sitting here and watching this -- maybe you're not -- your own argument, but the arguments before?  Aren't we learning in every case that we're hearing?  I -- I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: It's -- it's, in my mind, difficult to separate out what makes a person or stops a person from learning on a job.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: At any job, actually.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I opted in, Mr. Olson --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: --  for the very reason the residents might want to.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no, it didn't as interpreted.  You see, it's not -- it's that -- I concede everything you say:  It's a total learning experience, and it's a special learning experience.  The problem I was having that I wanted your answer to is  that they have for many, many years said:  Just because it's a pure learning experience and nothing but a pure learning experience, you still can't get this exemption unless the work is incident to that experience.  And by "incident" we mean it can't bulk too large --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- in respect to the whole. So the problem for you is not that it's not education.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It's that the work is the education.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Olson, there has been a concern expressed that if we accept your position that residents are students, it will have ramifications for other areas of the law, notably, the National Labor Relations Act.  Suppose the residents wanted to organize and collectively bargain.  If they're students, they can't do that. And let's take the Title VII and the other antidiscrimination in employment statutes.  If they're not employed, if they're students rather than employees, then they wouldn't be covered by that legislation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I looked it up in the dictionary, and the meaning number 1 b of "incident" is: an accompanying minor occurrence or -- occurrence or  condition.  Minor.  In other words, there's the big thing, and then there's the incident. Now, if that's the meaning, well, this says 40 is trying to get at whether it's minor or the whole --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, that's because --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- of the second meaning here.  It's very surprising, I found, first reading the statute in the last case, and now I'm reading the dictionary. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And here what it says is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: We don't know whether that's a step forward or backward.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It says:  something arising or resulting from something else of greater or principal import. So they're trying to work out, with that word "incident," is the studying of greater or principal import?  And what they're saying is, when it's 40 hours a week, this other thing, the studying, is not of greater import.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Rather, it's, let's say, of equal import.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If you have to draw the

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Why do you accept the word Incident is not in the statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, why isn't the answer that the -- that the noneducational aspect of the service has to be incidental to what they're doing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: If the question is whether someone is predominantly a student or an employee, why shouldn't we ask:  Why are they enrolled in this program, and why is the institution enrolling them in the program? Why are residents enrolled in the program? Are they enrolled in the program to make money, or are they enrolled in the program either because it's a licensing hurdle they have to clear or they want additional education, and why is the institution hiring them?  Is the institution hiring them to get the value of their services or is it hiring them for educational purposes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, in general, though. In general, why are residents -- why do medical school graduates become residents?  Do they do -- are they doing that because they want to earn the 40 to $50,000 a year that they're paid, or are they doing it for some other reason?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Because they don't work at schools.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What if they -- on average  they were paid $10,000 a year?  Would it be the same?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But I thought clinical work could qualify as a course.  Is that wrong?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But it certainly can if they're a -- if they can be a student in the last year of medical school, and they -- they're doing subintern-level work.  That's a clinical program where  they would be categorized as students.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: We now have a lot of briefs -- we now have a lot of briefs filed in this Court by -- in which a lot of the work is done by students in law school.  I assume they're getting credit for that.  Is that -- is that not a course?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But is it a course?  Is it not a course?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: I understand that.  I'm -- I'm questioning why you're resisting the proposition that clinical work can constitute a course.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Roberts, do you know the answer to the question I asked Mr. Olson; that is: Are all hospitals with resident programs schools?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Roberts, the Petitioners' brief says twice that there's some question.  Assuming that we hold that the -- the residents are subject to the FICA tax, there's some  question whether, even if they had to pay the tax, whether they would be eligible to receive Social Security benefits or, I take it, credit for four quarters in full.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Olson, you're not taking issue with what Mr. Roberts just said?  That is, in practice the -- Social Security looks to see -- they look at the W-2, see if the FICA tax was paid, and if it was, then -- then they get credit for Social Security.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: We have said that agencies can clarify situations that have been litigated and positions that they've lost on.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So, why is this any different?
